abstract.p: John V Burke letter responds to concerns about privacy perils in digital age

block.p: Re ''Voyeurism for the Entire Family,'' by Frank Rich (column, July 1):

Mr. Rich writes: ''Jeffrey Rosen, whose new book, 'The Unwanted Gaze,' is the definitive text on privacy perils in the digital age, feels sanguine about 'Big Brother.' 'It's silly to huff and puff about wanting to watch lurid television,' he says. 'It's a human impulse.' ''
Re ''Voyeurism for the Entire Family,'' by Frank Rich (column, July 1):

Mr. Rich writes: ''Jeffrey Rosen, whose new book, 'The Unwanted Gaze,' is the definitive text on privacy perils in the digital age, feels sanguine about 'Big Brother.' 'It's silly to huff and puff about wanting to watch lurid television,' he says. 'It's a human impulse.' ''
No doubt. But growing up entails learning to control one's human impulses.
With this new cycle of programs, television continues its successful project of turning the audience into self-indulgent, ill-mannered, undisciplined children.
JOHN V. BURKE San Francisco, July 1, 2000
